ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Every Little Thing, we looked for shapes in the pictures. We learned that we can find shapes all around us!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the words circle and square. Use the circle and square Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, you will match two cards. One card will show a shape and the other will show an object that is that shape.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Lay out the picture cards on the table with the pictures facing up.

Ask Can you pick a card that has a shape on it? What shape is it? How can you tell it is that shape? Then ask another child to find the cards that show the matching objects. Ask how they knew those cards match.
Extend Have children identify an object in the classroom that is the same shape as shown on their card.
Repeat Continue the activity until each child has had a chance to choose a shape and match that shape.

Talk About Shapes Point out to children that each shape has different characteristics. For example, a circle is round and flat. These descriptions help communicate information to others. Ask children to describe each shape, and to point out how they recognized it on the card.

Use prompts on the backs of cards to help children identify the objects and shapes on each card before beginning the activity. Provide limited choices for children to choose from when finding matching objects.

Place the cards face down so children cannot see the pictures. Then have them flip over two cards to check for a match. If there is not a match, guide them to flip the cards back over before the next child takes a turn.
Help Spanish speakers make the connection between shape names that are cognates, such as circle and circulo. Cognate awareness is a tool to help children understand a second language.
To encourage gross motor development, have children physically move around the classroom to identify shapes.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65182-9. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need drawing tools and paper, as well as Pattern Blocks or samples of shapes from the 6.2.1 Activity Cards.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Every Little Thing, we saw how there were shapes in the pictures. For example, we saw a circle in the sun, the boy’s hat, and the ball. We also noticed that working and playing together helped the children have more fun.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the word invite. Use the invite Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, you will invite a partner to work with you to draw shapes. I will name a shape, and you will draw as many things as you can that look like that shape.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Invite a child to work with you as a partner and announce that your shape is a triangle. Draw a slice of pizza, a party hat, etc. Model using cooperative language as you take turns with your partner.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Now you try! Invite a partner to make shape pictures with you.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Once each child has a partner, assign the pairs shapes and provide them with a sample of that shape.
Repeat Have the children select new partners and give them a new shape. Challenge them to draw more objects that look like that shape.

Talk About Inviting Discuss with children what they liked about being invited to work with a partner. Review the words they used to invite a friend, reminding them to use kind language such as “please” and “thank you”.
Help children recognize that gestures can be part of inviting someone else to play. Reaching out a hand, pointing to an object, smiling, and waiting are all gestures that support this skill.
Have children draw without the aid of the visual references of Pattern Blocks or Activity Cards. Ask children to describe what their shape looks like before they start drawing together.
If multiple children have the same home language that is not English, you can encourage them to invite each other to work together in that language.

Before starting the activity, allow children to touch and trace each shape as they say the name of the shape. This opportunity reinforces learning through their visual, auditory, and tactile modalities. It also allows students to remember the shape name in different parts of their brain, allowing for better recall in future situations.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65182-9. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need two different colors of Connecting Cubes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We read the book Every Little Thing. We talked about how the boy makes a mistake, but the adults help him feel better. We also talked about the patterns in the book. Today, we will practice making a mistake, pointing it out, then correcting it.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the word mistake. Use the mistake Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, I will make patterns with Connecting Cubes. I may make a mistake as I go. When I make a mistake, raise your hand, point out the mistake, and explain how I can fix it.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Arrange two colors of cubes in an AABB pattern. As you go, describe the pattern as an AABB pattern. Repeat the pattern twice. In the third repeat, change the cubes to reflect AABA. Look around for children to raise their hands as you add each cube.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Did I make a mistake? What was it? How can I fix it?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat Continue the activity with ABAB or AABB patterns. Pause after each cube and make at least two correct sets of the pattern before placing a “mistake” cube.

Talk About Patterns Ask children how they were able to catch your mistakes. Was it ever difficult to tell whether I made a mistake or not? What was hard about deciding what cube came next in the pattern?

Some children may have difficulty admitting to mistakes. Remind them that everyone makes mistakes, including teachers and adults. Encourage children to be supportive of their peers when someone makes a mistake.
Add a third color Connecting Cube and make ABCABC and AABBCC patterns.
Before beginning the activity, review the names of the colors you are using and how the letters correspond to patterns.

For children who have trouble describing the mistake and how to correct it, encourage them to point to the mistake and to the cube on the table that should go in its place. As they use gestures, describe what they are pointing out and encourage them to repeat after you.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65182-9. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need Pattern Blocks or other simple shapes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we sang Old MacDonald Had a Farm, we found a pattern in the words. We added to the pattern with our own words.

In this activity, you will invite a friend to make shape patterns with you. One of you will make a pattern of two shapes that repeats. Then you will ask your partner to say what shape comes next and put the next shape in a row.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Invite a child to be your partner. Create an ABAB pattern with two shapes, showing: circle, square, circle, square, circle. Then ask your partner to put down the next shape in the pattern (square).
Play Guide children to build patterns for their partners. Then, have them switch roles so that the child who was previously building a pattern is now extending the pattern.

Extend Once all children have made and extended patterns, remind children of how to create rhymes. Say an ABAB pattern with words or sounds, such as head, chair, thread, bear. (Don’t worry about it making sense.) Continue the pattern, like fed, air, shed, and then pause for the group to fill in a new word that rhymes. Repeat with other patterns.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Think about the patterns of shapes you made. How did you know what shape came next in the pattern? How was it different when making patterns with rhyming sounds?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: If children are having difficulty identifying the pattern independently, have both children in the pair work together to build the pattern and discuss which shape comes next.
After children guess the next shape in the sequence, ask them to draw the shape on a piece of paper, and then place it at the end of the pattern instead of using a Pattern Block.

Review shape names and naming patterns with letters. Encourage children to create rhymes in whatever language they prefer as a way of focusing on the rhyming sound and pattern matching and not the language.
Guide both children in the pair to build patterns at the same time. This gives both partners something to focus on simultaneously.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65182-9. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
